net.usikkert.kouinject.generics
Class GenericsHelper

java.lang.Object
  net.usikkert.kouinject.generics.GenericsHelper

public final class GenericsHelper
extends Object

Helper class for common operations on generics.

Author:
Christian Ihle

Method Detail

getGenericArgumentAsType

public static Type getGenericArgumentAsType(Type type)
Returns the generic argument used on the type, as a type.

Example: the type Set<List<String>> would return List<String>.

Parameters:
type - The type to get the generic argument from. Supports only 1 generic argument.
Returns:
The argument of the type, as a type.

getGenericArgumentAsClass

public static Class<?> getGenericArgumentAsClass(Type type)
Returns the generic argument used on the type, as a class.

Example: the type Set<List<String>> would return the class for List.

Parameters:
type - The type to get the generic argument from. Supports only 1 generic argument.
Returns:
The argument of the type, as a class.

Example: the type Set<List<String>> would return the class for Set.

getAsClassOrNull

public static Class<?> getAsClassOrNull(Type type)
Returns the type as a class, if possible.

Example: the type Set<List<String>> would return the class for Set.

Parameters:
type - The type to get as a class.
Returns:
The type as a class, or null if the class could not be determined.

getArrayClassFromGenericArray

public static Class<?> getArrayClassFromGenericArray(GenericArrayType genericArrayType)
Gets the actual array class representing the generic array type.

Example: a generic array type for String would return String[]. A generic array type with a nested generic array type with a String would return String[][].

Returns null when the generic array type does not hold a class or another generic array type, like a List<String>[].

Parameters:
genericArrayType - The generic array type to get the array class from.
Returns:
The array class, or null if not found.

isClass

public static boolean isClass(Type type)
Checks if the type is a class, as opposed to a type with generic parameters.

Example: String would return true, List<String> would return false.

Parameters:
type - The type to check.
Returns:
If the type is a regular class.

isParameterizedType

public static boolean isParameterizedType(Type type)
Checks if the type has generic parameters, as opposed to a regular class.

Example: String would return false, List<String> would return true.

Parameters:
type - The type to check.
Returns:
If the type is parameterized.

isTypeVariable

public static boolean isTypeVariable(Type type)
Checks if the type is a type variable, as opposed to an actual type.

Example: T would return true, Number would return false.

Parameters:
type - The type to check.
Returns:
If the type is a type variable.

isWildcard

public static boolean isWildcard(Type type)
Checks if the type is a wildcard, as opposed to a class or a type with generic parameters.

Example: ? extends Number would return true, Number would return false.

Parameters:
type - The type to check.
Returns:
If the type is a wildcard.

isGenericArrayType

public static boolean isGenericArrayType(Type type)
Checks if the type is a generic array type.

Generic array types appear when using arrays inside a generic type, or when the generic type itself is an array.

Parameters:
type - The type to check.
Returns:
If the type is a generic array type.

isAssignableFrom

public static boolean isAssignableFrom(Type thisType,
                                       Type thatType)
Determines if "this" type is either the same as, or a supertype of, "that" type.

The assignability logic is mostly based on the principle that if it compiles, it's assignable. Supports the following comparisons:

  • Class vs class - Class 1 must be assignable from class 2.
  • Array class vs array class - Array class 1 must be assignable from array class 2, and have the same dimensions.
  • Parameterized type vs parameterized type - The raw class of type 1 must be assignable from the raw class of type 2, and all the parameters of both must be equal.
  • Wildcard vs wildcard - The bounds of each wildcard must be assignable from each other.
  • Wildcard vs class or parameterized type - The bounds of the wildcard must be assignable from the class or type.
  • Class vs parameterized type - Class 1 must be assignable from the raw class of type 2.

Does not support parameterized type vs class.

Type variables in "that" will be automatically resolved to an actual type, if possible. "This" as a type variable is not automatically resolved, as it requires knowing the class the type belongs to. Can be solved with mapTypeVariablesToActualTypes(Class) and wrapTypeAndReplaceTypeVariables(java.lang.reflect.Type, TypeMap) before using this method.

Parameters:
thisType - The left hand side, usually an injection point.
thatType - The right hand side, usually a bean.
Returns:
If "this" is assignable from "that".

mapTypeVariablesToActualTypes

public static TypeMap mapTypeVariablesToActualTypes(Class<?> aClass)
Creates a map with all the type variables used on the specified class as keys, and their actual types as values.

All super-classes and super-interfaces of the specified class are also searched. If no actual type is found for a type variable, then the value for that key will be null.

Example:

   class Basket<T> {}
   class FruitBasket extends Basket<Fruit> {}

If FruitBasket.class was the parameter, you would get a map with T as key, and Fruit.class as value. If Basket.class was the parameter then you would get a map with T as key, and null as value.

Parameters:
aClass - The class to search for type variables on.
Returns:
A map with the type variables and the actual types that was found on the specified class.

wrapTypeAndReplaceTypeVariables

public static Type wrapTypeAndReplaceTypeVariables(Type type,
                                                   TypeMap typeMap)
Takes a type, and replaces any type variables with an actual type from the type map.

Supports parameterized types, wildcards and generic array types. The replacement is recursive, so if the type variable is in a nested type then the whole hierarchy of types will be wrapped. If no actual type is found in the map, then the type variable is kept as is.

Example:

If type is List<Basket<T>>, and map contains key T and value Fruit.class, then the wrapped type will be List<Basket<Fruit>>.

Parameters:
type - The type to wrap.
typeMap - The map containing the actual types to use when replacing type variables.
Returns:
A wrapped type with type variables replaced with actual types from the map.
See Also:
mapTypeVariablesToActualTypes(Class)
